paludism: The morbid phenomena produced by dwelling among marshes;malarial disease or disposition.
panel: A sunken compartment with raised margins, molded or otherwise,as in ceilings, wainscotings, etc.
prickpunch: A pointed steel punch, to prick a mark on metal.
pulsate: To throb, as a pulse; to beat, as the heart.The heart of a viper or frog will continue to pulsate long after itis taken from the body. E. Darwin.
prevenient: Going before; preceding; hence, preventive. "Prevenient gracedescending." Milton.
pandemic: Affecting a whole people or a number of countries; everywhereepidemic.-- n.
potsherd: A piece or fragment of a broken pot. Job ii. 8.
pillwort: Any plant of the genus Pilularia; minute aquatic cryptograms,with small pill-shaped fruit; -- sometimes called peppergrass.
pothole: A circular hole formed in the rocky beds of rivers by thegrinding action of stones or gravel whirled round by the water inwhat was at first a natural depression of the rock.
potstone: A variety of steatite sometimes manufactured into culinaryvessels.
pentad: Any element, atom, or radical, having a valence of five, orwhich can be combined with, substituted for, or compared with, fiveatoms of hydrogen or other monad; as, nitrogen is a pentad in theammonium compounds.
plongee: A slope or sloping toward the front; as, the plongée of aparapet; the plongée of a shell in its course. [Sometimes writtenplonge.]
passive: Inactive; inert; not showing strong affinity; as, redphosphorus is comparatively passive.
plagioclase: A general term used of any triclinic feldspar. See the Noteunder Feldspar.
percutient: Striking; having the power of striking.-- n.
polypodium: A genus of plants of the order Filices or ferns. Thefructifications are in uncovered roundish points, called sori,scattered over the inferior surface of the frond or leaf. There arenumerous species.
preponderate: To exceed in weight; hence, to incline or descend, as the scaleof a balance; figuratively, to exceed in influence, power, etc.;hence; to incline to one side; as, the affirmative sidepreponderated.That is no just balance in which the heaviest side will notpreponderate. Bp. Wilkins.
pediment: Originally, in classical architecture, the triangular spaceforming the gable of a simple roof; hence, a similar form used as adecoration over porticoes, doors, windows, etc.; also, a rounded orbroken frontal having a similar position and use. See Temple.
potential: In the theory of gravitation, or of other forces acting inspace, a function of the rectangular coordinates which determine theposition of a point, such that its differential coefficients withrespect to the coördinates are equal to the components of the forceat the point considered; -- also called potential function, or forcefunction. It is called also Newtonian potential when the force isdirected to a fixed center and is inversely as the square of thedistance from the center.
portcrayon: A metallic handle with a clasp for holding a crayon.
post-: A prefix signifying behind, back, after; as, postcommissure,postdot, postscript.
pated: Having a pate; -- used only in composition; as, long-pated;shallow-pated.
pygostyle: The plate of bone which forms the posterior end of thevertebral column in most birds; the plowshare bone; the vomer. It isformed by the union of a number of the last caudal vertebræ, andsupports the uropigium.
payee: The person to whom money is to be, or has been, paid; theperson named in a bill or note, to whom, or to whose order, theamount is promised or directed to be paid. See Bill of exchange,under Bill.
precipitately: In a precipitate manner; headlong; hastily; rashly. Swift.
phreatic: Subterranean; -- applied to sources supplying wells.
pyrotritartaric: Designating an acid which is more commonly called uric acid.
pricksong: Music written, or noted, with dots or points; -- so called fromthe points or dots with which it is noted down. [Obs.]He fights as you sing pricksong. Shak.
perplexiveness: The quality of being perplexing; tendency to perplex. [Obs.]Dr. H. More.
petrific: Petrifying; petrifactive.Death with his mace petrific, cold and dry. Milton.
permission: The act of permitting or allowing; formal consent;authorization; leave; license or liberty granted.High permission of all-ruling Heaven. Milton.You have given me your permission for this address. Dryden.
perturber: One who, or that which, perturbs, or cause perturbation.
pelican state: Louisiana; -- a nickname alluding to the device on its seal.
phytotomy: The dissection of plants; vegetable anatomy.
provisional: Of the nature of a provision; serving as a provision for thetime being; -- used of partial or temporary arrangements; as, aprovisional government; a provisional treaty.
petrescent: Petrifying; converting into stone; as, petrescent water. Boyle.
printing in: A process by which cloud effects or other features not in theoriginal negative are introduced into a photograph. Portions, such asthe sky, are covered while printing and the blank space thus reservedis filled in by printing from another negative.
pithsome: Pithy; robust. [R.] "Pithsome health and vigor." R. D.Blackmore.
plesiosaurus: A genus of large extinct marine reptiles, having a very longneck, a small head, and paddles for swimming. It lived in theMesozoic age.
proveditor: One employed to procure supplies, as for an army, a steamer,etc.; a purveyor; one who provides for another. Jer. Taylor.
panislamism: A desire or plan for the union of all Mohammedan nations forthe conquest of the world.
prevaricator: A sham dealer; one who colludes with a defendant in a shamprosecution.
prong-hoe: A hoe with prongs to break the earth.
pear: The fleshy pome, or fruit, of a rosaceous tree (Pyruscommunis), cultivated in many varieties in temperate climates; also,the tree which bears this fruit. See Pear family, below. Pear blight.(a) (Bot.) A name of two distinct diseases of pear trees, bothcausing a destruction of the branches, viz., that caused by a minuteinsect (Xyleborus pyri), and that caused by the freezing of the sapin winter. A. J. Downing. (b) (Zoöl.) A very small beetle (Xyleboruspyri) whose larvæ bore in the twigs of pear trees and cause them towither.-- Pear family (Bot.), a suborder of rosaceous plants (Pomeæ),characterized by the calyx tube becoming fleshy in fruit, and,combined with the ovaries, forming a pome. It includes the apple,pear, quince, service berry, and hewthorn.-- Pear gauge (Physics), a kind of gauge for measuring theexhaustion of an air-pump receiver; -- so called because consistingin part of a pear-shaped glass vessel. Pear shell (Zoöl.), any marinegastropod shell of the genus Pyrula, native of tropical seas; -- socalled from the shape.-- Pear slug (Zoöl.), the larva of a sawfly which is very injuriousto the foliage of the pear tree.
palisading: ) A row of palisades set in the ground.
pockmark: A mark or pit made by smallpox.
pierid: Any butterfly of the genus Pieris and related genera. SeeCabbage butterfly, under Cabbage.
putt: A stroke made on the putting green to play the ball into ahole.
perineurial: Surrounding nerves or nerve fibers; of or pertaining to theperineurium.
photograph: A picture or likeness obtained by photography.
petronel: A sort of hand cannon, or portable firearm, used in France inthe 15th century.
pentahedral: Having five sides; as, a pentahedral figure.
passeriform: Like or belonging to the Passeres.
pentaptych: A picture, or combination of pictures, consisting of acenterpiece and double folding doors or wings, as for an altarpiece.
pavon: A small triangular flag, esp. one attached to a knight's lance;a pennon.
pistol: The smallest firearm used, intended to be fired from one hand,-- now of many patterns, and bearing a great variety of names. SeeIllust. of Revolver. Pistol carbine, a firearm with a removable but-piece, and thus capable of being used either as a pistol or acarbine.-- Pistol pipe (Metal.), a pipe in which the blast for a furnace isheated, resembling a pistol in form.-- Pistol shot. (a) The discharge of a pistol. (b) The distance towhich a pistol can propel a ball.
potestate: A chief ruler; a potentate. [Obs.] Wyclif. "An irouspotestate." Chaucer.
proselyte: A new convert especially a convert to some religion orreligious sect, or to some particular opinion, system, or party;thus, a Gentile converted to Judaism, or a pagan converted toChristianity, is a proselyte.Ye [Scribes and Pharisees] compass sea and land to make oneproselyte. Matt. xxiii. 15.Fresh confidence the speculatist takes From every harebrainedproselyte he makes. Cowper.
printing: The act, art, or practice of impressing letters, characters, orfigures on paper, cloth, or other material; the business of aprinter, including typesetting and presswork, with their adjuncts;typography; also, the act of producing photographic prints. Blockprinting. See under Block.-- Printing frame (Photog.), a shallow box, usually having a glassfront, in which prints are made by exposure to light.-- Printing house, a printing office.-- Printing ink, ink used in printing books, newspapers, etc. It iscomposed of lampblack or ivory black mingled with linseed or nut oil,made thick by boiling and burning. Other ingredients are employed forthe finer qualities. Ure.-- Printing office, a place where books, pamphlets, or newspapers,etc., are printed.-- Printing paper, paper used in the printing of books, pamphlets,newspapers, and the like, as distinguished from writing paper,wrapping paper, etc.-- Printing press, a press for printing, books, newspaper,handbills, etc.-- Printing wheel, a wheel with letters or figures on its periphery,used in machines for paging or numbering, or in ticket-printingmachines, typewriters, etc.; a type wheel.
partnership: A contract between two or more competent persons for joiningtogether their money, goods, labor, and skill, or any or all of them,under an understanding that there shall be a communion of profitbetween them, and for the purpose of carrying on a legal trade,business, or adventure. Kent. Story.
pyaemic: Of or pertaining to pyæmia; of the nature of pyæmia.
prostitute: Openly given up to lewdness; devoted to base or infamouspurposes.Made bold by want, and prostitute for bread. Prior
pyroboric: Pertaining to derived from, or designating, an acid, H2B4O7(called also tetraboric acid), which is the acid ingredient ofordinary borax, and is obtained by heating boric acid.
particle: A subordinate word that is never inflected (a preposition,conjunction, interjection); or a word that can not be used except incompositions; as, ward in backward, ly in lovely.
paracorolla: A secondary or inner corolla; a corona, as of the Narcissus.
pincher: One who, or that which, pinches.
pebbly: Full of pebbles; pebbled. "A hard, pebbly bottom." Johnson.
purlieu: In root construction, a horizontal member supported on theprincipals and supporting the common rafters.
phasing transformer: Any of several transformers (there must be at least two) forchanging phase.
precipitation: The act or process from a solution.
pantophagist: A person or an animal that has the habit of eating all kinds offood.
pressman: One of a press gang, who aids in forcing men into the navalservice; also, one forced into the service.
petitioning: The act of presenting apetition; a supplication.
puppetish: Resembling a puppet in appearance or action; of the nature of apuppet.
philanthropistic: Pertaining to, or characteristic of, a philanthropist. [R.]Carlyle.
pari-: A combining form signifying equal; as, paridigitate,paripinnate.
perthite: A kind of feldspar consisting of a laminated intertexture ofalbite and orthoclase, usually of different colors.-- Per*thit"ic, a.
plover: Any one of numerous species of limicoline birds belonging tothe family Charadridæ, and especially those belonging to thesubfamily Charadrinsæ. They are prized as game birds.
private: A common soldier; a soldier below the grade of anoncommissioned officer. Macaulay.
precessional: Of or pertaining to pression; as, the precessional movement ofthe equinoxes.
parvenu: An upstart; a man newly risen into notice.
petrohyoid: Pertaining to petrous, oe periotic, portion of the skull andthe hyoid arch; as, the petrohyoid muscles of the frog.
phosgene: Producing, or produced by, the action of light; -- formerlyused specifically to designate a gas now called carbonyl chloride.See Carbonyl.
pacifico: A peaceful person; -- applied specif. by the Spaniards to thenatives in Cuba and the Philippine Islands who did not oppose theSpanish arms.
prosimetrical: Consisting both of prose and verse. Clarke.
prosocoele: The entire cavity of the prosencephalon. B. G. Wilder.
perspirative: Performing the act of perspiration; perspiratory.
pinxit: A word appended to the artist's name or initials on a painting,or engraved copy of a painting; as, Rubens pinxit, Rubens painted(this).
plantule: The embryo which has begun its development in the act ofgermination.
poller: One who polls; specifically: (a) One who polls or lops trees.(b) One who polls or cuts hair; a barber. [R.] (c) One who extorts orplunders. [Obs.] Bacon. (d) One who registers voters, or one whoenters his name as a voter.
prepared: Made fit or suitable; adapted; ready; as, prepared food;prepared questions.-- Pre*par"ed*ly, adv. Shak.-- Pre*par"ed*ness, n.
propound: To propose or name as a candidate for admission to communionwith a church.
pyuria: A morbid condition in which pus is discharged in the urine.
photogravure: A photoengraving; also, the process by which such a picture isproduced.
paleogaean: Of or pertaining to the Eastern hemisphere. [Written alsopalæogæan.]
petrine: Of or pertaining to St.Peter; as, the Petrine Epistles.
phase converter: A machine for converting an alternating current into analternating current of a different number of phases and the samefrequency.
pepper dulse: A variety of edible seaweed (Laurencia pinnatifida)distinguished for its pungency. [Scot.] Lindley.
pundit: A learned man; a teacher; esp., a Brahman versed in theSanskrit language, and in the science, laws, and religion of theHindoos; in Cashmere, any clerk or native official. [Written alsopandit.] [India]
pulicene: Pertaining to, or abounding in, fleas; pulicose.
physiocrat: One of the followers of Quesnay of France, who, in the 18thcentury, founded a system of political economy based upon thesupremacy of natural order. F. A. Walker.-- Phys`i*o*crat"ic, a.
precontract: To contract, engage, or stipulate previously.
perpetual calendar: A calendar that can be used perpetually or over a wide range ofyears. That of Capt. Herschel covers, as given below, dates from 1750to 1961 only, but is capable of indefinite extension.
prate: To talk much and to little purpose; to be loquacious; to speakfoolishly; to babble.To prate and talk for life and honor. Shak.And make a fool presume to prate of love. Dryden.
peliom: A variety of iolite, of a smoky blue color; pelioma.
phthiriasis: A disease (morbus pediculous) consisting in the excessivemultiplication of lice on the human body.
presumer: One who presumes; also, an arrogant person. Sir H. Wotton.
passageway: A way for passage; a hall. See Passage, 5.
patrolman: One who patrols; a watchman; especially, a policeman whopatrols a particular precinct of a town or city.
playbook: A book of dramatic compositions; a book of the play. Swift.
pauperization: The act or process of reducing to pauperism. C. Kingsley.
perineorrhaphy: The operation of sewing up a ruptured perineum.
promise: An engagement by one person to another, either in words or inwriting, but properly not under seal, for the performance ornonperformance of some particular thing. The word promise is used todenote the mere engagement of a person, without regard to theconsideration for it, or the corresponding duty of the party to whomit is made. Chitty. Parsons. Burrill.
paripinnate: Pinnate with an equal number of leaflets on each side; havingno odd leaflet at the end.
pupilage: The state of being a pupil.As sons of kings, loving in pupilage, Have turned to tyrants whenthey came to power. Tennyson.
protococcus: A genus of minute unicellular algæ including the red snow plant(Protococcus nivalis).
parietic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid found in the lichenParmelia parietina, and called also chrysophanic acid.
plasmator: A former; a fashioner. [R.] "The sovereign plasmator, GodAlmighty." Urquhart.
proseminary: A seminary which prepares pupils for a higher institution. T.Warton.
paleichthyes: A comprehensive division of fishes which includes theelasmobranchs and ganoids. [Written also Palæichthyes.]
platitudinous: Abounding in platitudes; of the nature of platitudes; utteringplatitudes.-- Plat`i*tu"di*nous*ness, n.
pantler: The servant or officer, in a great family, who has charge ofthe bread and the pantry. [Obs.] Shak.
passional: Of or pertaining to passion or the passions; exciting,influenced by, or ministering to, the passions.-- n.
plugger: One who, or that which, plugs.
pinion: A moth of the genus Lithophane, as L. antennata, whose larvabores large holes in young peaches and apples.
pawnee: One or two whom a pledge is delivered as security; one whotakes anything in pawn.
pupipara: A division of Diptera in which the young are born in a stagelike the pupa. It includes the sheep tick, horse tick, and otherparasites. Called also Homaloptera.
pessimism: The opinion or doctrine that everything in nature is orderedfor or tends to the worst, or that the world is wholly evil; --opposed to Ant: optimism.
polypidom: A coral, or corallum; also, one of the coral-like structuremade by bryozoans and hydroids.
pontifice: Bridgework; structure or edifice of a bridge. [R.] Milton.
personalism: The quality or state of being personal; personality. [R.]
prier: One who pries; one who inquires narrowly and searches, or isinquisitive.So pragmatical a prier he is into divine secrets. Fuller.
promulge: To promulgate; to publish or teach. Blackstone.Extraordinary doctrines these for the age in which they werepromulged. Prescott.
proboscis: A hollow organ or tube attached to the head, or connected withthe mouth, of various animals, and generally used in taking food ordrink; a snout; a trunk.
propylaeum: Any court or vestibule before a building or leading into anyinclosure.
photoluminescent: Luminescent by exposure to light waves. --Pho`to*lu`mi*nes"cence (#), n.
puke: To eject the contests of the stomach; to vomit; to spew.The infant Mewling and puking in the nurse's arms. Shak.
peopler: A settler; an inhabitant. "Peoplers of the peaceful glen." J.S. Blackie.
politician: Cunning; using artifice; politic; artful. "Ill-meaningpolitician lords." Milton.
pseudobranchia: A rudimentary branchia, or gill.-- Pseu`do*bran"chi*al, a.
pulpous: Containing pulp; pulpy. " Pulpous fruit." J. Philips.-- Pulp"ous*ness, n.
passiveness: The quality or state of being passive; unresisting submission.To be an effect implies passiveness, or the being subject to thepower and action of its cause. J. Edwards.
pycnaspidean: Having the posterior side of the tarsus covered with smallirregular scales; -- said of certain birds.
purveyance: A providing necessaries for the sovereign by buying them at anappraised value in preference to all others, and oven without theowner's consent. This was formerly a royal prerogative, but has longbeen abolished. Wharton.
poon: A name for several East Indian, or their wood, used for themasts and spars of vessels, as Calophyllum angustifolium, C.inophullum, and Sterculia foetida; -- called also peon.
plagiostomi: An order of fishes including the sharks and rays; -- calledalso Plagiostomata.
pica: The genus that includes the magpies.
pansied: Covered or adorned with pansies. "The pansied grounds." Darwin.
provection: A carrying forward, as of a final letter, to a following word;as, for example, a nickname for an ekename.
pollinium: A coherent mass of pollen, as in the milkweed and most orchids.
planarian: One of the Planarida, or Dendrocoela; any turbellarian worm.-- Pla*na"ri*an, a.
phrenosin: A nitrogenous body, related to cerebrin, supposed to exist inthe brain.
phrasal: Of the nature of a phrase; consisting of a phrase; as, aphrasal adverb. Earlc.
periodide: An iodide containing a higher proportion of iodine than anyother iodide of the same substance or series.
pocketbook: A small book or case for carrying papers, money, etc., in thepocket; also, a notebook for the pocket.
pinacone: A white crystalline substance related to the glycols, and madefrom acetone; hence, by extension, any one of a series of substancesof which pinacone proper is the type. [Written also pinakone.]
pigskin: The skin of a pig, -- used chiefly for making saddles; hence, acolloquial or slang term for a saddle.
periblem: Nascent cortex, or immature cellular bark.
philomathy: The love of learning or letters.
paduasoy: A rich and heavy silk stuff. [Written also padesoy.]
puppet: The upright support for the bearing of the spindle in a lathe.Puppet master. Same as Puppetman.-- Puppet play, a puppet show.-- Puppet player, one who manages the motions of puppets.-- Puppet show, a mock drama performed by puppets moved by wires.-- Puppet valve, a valve in the form of a circular disk, whichcovers a hole in its seat, and opens by moving bodily away from theseat while remaining parallel with it, -- used in steam engines,pumps, safety valves, etc. Its edge is often beveled, and fits in aconical recess in the seat when the valve is closed. See the valvesshown in Illusts. of Plunger pump, and Safety valve, under Plunger,and Safety.
papillary: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a papilla or papillæ;bearing, or covered with, papillæ; papillose.
placodermi: An extinct group of fishes, supposed to be ganoids. The bodyand head were covered with large bony plates. See Illust. underPterichthys, and Coccosteus.
pontage: A duty or tax paid for repairing bridges. Ayliffe.
peignoir: A woman's loose dressing sack; hence, a loose morning gown orwrapper.
pseudo-symmetry: A kind of symmetry characteristic of certain crystals whichfrom twinning, or other causes, come to resemble forms of a systemother than that to which they belong, as the apparently hexagonalprisms of aragonite.
preignition: Ignition in an internal-combustion engine while the inlet valveis open or before compression is completed.
proxene: An officer who had the charge of showing hospitality to thosewho came from a friendly city or state.
purfling: Ornamentation on the border of a thing; specifically, theinlaid border of a musical instrument, as a violin.
putour: A keeper of a brothel; a procurer. [Obs.] Chaucer.
parroter: One who simply repeats what he has heard. [R.] J. S. Mill.
permeation: The act of permeating, passing through, or spreadingthroughout, the pores or interstices of any substance.Here is not a mere involution only, but a spiritual permeation andinexistence. Bp. Hall.
preachify: To discourse in the manner of a preacher. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
plurilocular: Having several cells or loculi; specifically (Bot.),
purposeless: Having no purpose or result; objectless. Bp. Hall.-- Pur"pose*less*ness, n.
panicle: A pyramidal form of inflorescence, in which the cluster isloosely branched below and gradually simpler toward the end.
prescription: A direction of a remedy or of remedies for a disease, and themanner of using them; a medical recipe; also, a prescribed remedy.
proctorship: The office or dignity of a proctor; also, the term of hisoffice. Clarendon.
principia: First principles; fundamental beginnings; elements; as.Newton's Principia.
pottern: Of or pertaining to potters. Pottern ore, a species of orewhich, from its aptness to vitrify like the glazing of potter'swares, the miners call by this name. Boyle.
perichaetous: Surrounded by setæ; -- said of certain earthworms (genusPerichætus).
promisor: One who engages or undertakes; a promiser. Burrill.
perterebration: The act of boring through. [Obs.] Ainsworth.
propugn: To contend for; to defend; to vindicate. [Obs.] Hammond.
podalgia: pain in the foot, due to gout, rheumatism, etc.
polygonal: Having many angles. Polygonal numbers, certain figuratenumbers. See under Figurate.
palempore: A superior kind of dimity made in India, -- used for bedcoverings. [Written also palampore, palampoor, etc.] De Colange.
prismatically: In the form on manner of a prism; by means of a prism.
petitionarily: By way of begging the question; by an assumption. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
profiling: In the construction of fieldworks, the erection at properintervals of wooden profiles, to show to the workmen the sectionalform of the parapets at those points.
percussive: Striking against; percutient; as, percussive force.
parceling: Long, narrow slips of canvas daubed with tar and wound about arope like a bandage, before it is served; used, also, in mousing onthe stayes, etc.
polymerization: The act or process of changing to a polymeric form; thecondition resulting from such change.
parson: A person who represents a parish in its ecclesiastical andcorporate capacities; hence, the rector or incumbent of a parochialchurch, who has full possession of all the rights thereof, with thecure of souls.
placid: Pleased; contented; unruffied; undisturbed; serene; peaceful;tranquil; quiet; gentle. "That placid aspect and meek regard."Milton. "Sleeping . . . the placid sleep of infancy." Macaulay.
pythagorize: To speculate after the manner of Pythagoras.
photoprint: Any print made by a photomechanical process.
papyrus: A tall rushlike plant (Cyperus Papyrus) of the Sedge family,formerly growing in Egypt, and now found in Abyssinia, Syria, Sicily,etc. The stem is triangular and about an inch thick.
perlitic: Relating to or resembling perlite, or pearlstone; as, theperlitic structure of certain rocks. See Pearlite.
presensation: Previous sensation, notion, or idea. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
praenomen: The first name of a person, by which individuals of the samefamily were distinguished, answering to our Christian name, as Caius,Lucius, Marcus, etc.
pomace: The substance of apples, or of similar fruit, crushed bygrinding.
persuader: One who, or that which, persuades or influences. "Powerfulpersuaders." Milton.
peacemaker: One who makes peace by reconciling parties that are atvariance. Matt. v. 9. --Peace"mak`ing, n.
pactolian: Pertaining to the Pactolus, a river in ancient Lydia famous forits golden sands.
parasol: A kind of small umbrella used by women as a protection from thesun.
pomme blanche: The prairie turnip. See under Prairie.
pupigerous: Bearing or containing a pupa; -- said of dipterous larvæ whichdo not molt when the pupa is formed within them.
penelope: A genus of curassows, including the guans.
polydactylism: The possession of more that the normal number of digits.
perish: To be destroyed; to pass away; to become nothing; to be lost;to die; hence, to wither; to waste away.I perish with hunger! Luke xv. 17.Grow up and perish, as the summer fly. Milton.The thoughts of a soul that perish in thinking. Locke.
phenanthrene: A complex hydrocarbon, C14H10, found in coal tar, and obtainedas a white crystalline substance with a bluish fluorescence.
paragenic: Originating in the character of the germ, or at the firstcommencement of an individual; -- said of peculiarities of structure,character, etc.
poacher: The American widgeon. [Local, U.S.] Sea poacher (Zoöl.), thelyrie.
pteroceras: A genus of large marine gastropods having the outer border ofthe lip divided into lobes; -- called also scorpion shell.
pearl: A fringe or border. [Obs.] -- v. t.
plagiotropic: Having the longer axis inclined away from the vertical line.
psora: A cutaneous disease; especially, the itch.
polygraph: Pertaining to, or employed in, polygraphy; as, a polygraphicinstrument.
portate: Borne not erect, but diagonally athwart an escutcheon; as, across portate.
preterpluperfect: Old name of the tense also called pluperfect.
platonic: A follower of Plato; a Platonist.
postfrontal: Situated behind the frontal bone or the frontal region of theskull; -- applied especially to a bone back of and below the frontalin many animals.-- n.
proctor: One who is employed to manage to affairs of another.Specifically:(a) A person appointed to collect alms for those who could not go outto beg for themselves, as lepers, the bedridden, etc.; hence abeggar. [Obs.] Nares.(b) (Eng. Law) An officer employed in admiralty and ecclesiasticalcauses. He answers to an attorney at common law, or to a solicitor inequity. Wharton.(c) (Ch. of Eng.) A representative of the clergy in convocation.(d) An officer in a university or college whose duty it is to enforceobedience to the laws of the institution.
pipe line: A line of pipe with pumping machinery and apparatus forconveying liquids, esp. petroleum, between distant points.
phaethon: The son of Helios (Phoebus), that is, the son of light, or ofthe sun. He is fabled to have obtained permission to drive thechariot of the sun, in doing which his want of skill would have setthe world on fire, had he not been struck with a thunderbolt byJupiter, and hurled headlong into the river Po.
personalize: To make personal. "They personalize death." H. Spencer.
prolonger: One who, or that which, causes an extension in time or space.
pincushion: A small cushion, in which pins may be stuck for use.
pentastich: A composition consisting of five verses.
perpetuation: The act of making perpetual, or of preserving from extinctionthrough an endless existence, or for an indefinite period of time;continuance. Sir T. Browne.
pernot furnace: A reverberatory furnace with a circular revolving hearth, --used in making steel.
pilose: Clothed thickly with pile or soft down.
pulmonic: Relating to, or affecting the lungs; pulmonary.-- n.
pigwidgeon: A cant word for anything petty or small. It is used by Draytonas the name of a fairy.
pettitoes: The toes or feet of a pig, -- often used as food; sometimes, incontempt, the human feet. Shak.
pillow lace: Lace made by hand with bobbins on a pillow.
pecopteris: An extensive genus of fossil ferns; -- so named from theregular comblike arrangement of the leaflets.
permulator: A special form of rotary converter with stationary commutatorand rotating brushes, in which the exciting field is induced by thealternating current in a short-circuited magnetic core instead ofbeing produced by an external magnet.
platypus: The duck mole. See under Duck.
pessimize: To hold or advocate the doctrine of pessimism. London Sat. Rev.
propagandism: The art or practice of propagating tenets or principles; zealin propagating one's opinions.
piggery: A place where swine are kept.
probang: A slender elastic rod, as of whalebone, with a sponge on theend, for removing obstructions from the esophagus, etc.
phthalic: Pertaining to, or designating, a dibasic acid obtained by theoxidation of naphthalene and allied substances. Phthalic acid(Chem.), a white crystalline substance, C6H4.(CO2H)2, analogous tobenzoic acid, and employed in the brilliant dyestuffs called thephthaleins.
pains: Labor; toilsome effort; care or trouble taken; -- plural inform, but used with a singular or plural verb, commonly the former.And all my pains is sorted to no proof. Shak.The pains they had taken was very great. Clarendon.The labored earth your pains have sowed and tilled. Dryden.
pulsion: The act of driving forward; propulsion; -- opposed to Ant:suction or Ant: traction. [R.]
perbromic: Pertaining to, or designating, the highest oxygen acid, HBrO4,of bromine.
pliancy: The quality or state of being pliant in sense; as, the pliancyof a rod. "Avaunt all specious pliancy of mind." Wordsworth.
pedipalpus: One of the second pair of mouth organs of arachnids. In somethey are leglike, but in others, as the scorpion, they terminate in aclaw.
presbyope: One who has presbyopia; a farsighted person.
pedantize: To play the pedant; to use pedantic expressions. [R.]
pardonable: Admitting of pardon; not requiring the excution of penalty;venial; excusable; -- applied to the offense or to the offender; as,a pardonable fault, or culprit.
perrie: Precious stones; jewels. [Obs.] [Written also perre, perrye,etc.] Chaucer.
pirameter: A dynamometer for ascertaining the power required to drawcarriages over roads.
paper: Of or pertaining to paper; made of paper; resembling paper;existing only on paper; unsubstantial; as, a paper box; a paper army.
plagiocephaly: Oblique lateral deformity of the skull.
phosphinic: Pertaining to, or designating, certain acids analogous to thephosphonic acids, but containing two hydrocarbon radicals, andderived from the secondary phosphines by oxidation.
pentecostal: Of or pertaining to Pentecost or to Whitsuntide.
predesign: To design or purpose beforehand; to predetermine. Mitford.
poleless: Without a pole; as, a poleless chariot.
prensation: The act of seizing with violence. [Obs.] Barrow .
presswork: The art of printing from the surface of type, plates, orengravings in relief, by means of a press; the work so done.MacKellar.
pepper box: A buttress on the left-hand wall of a fives court as the gameis played at Eton College, England.
percipient: Having the faculty of perception; perceiving; as, a percipientbeing. Bentley.-- n.
pi: A mass of type confusedly mixed or unsorted. [Written alsopie.]
paigle: A species of Primula, either the cowslip or the primrose.[Written also pagle, pagil, peagle, and pygil.]
prognathi: A comprehensive group of mankind, including those that haveprognathous jaws.
pistillaceous: Growing on, or having nature of, the pistil; of or pertainingto a pistil. Barton.
polony: A kind of sausage made of meat partly cooked.
polygyn: A plant of the order Polygynia.
portmote: In old English law, a court, or mote, held in a port town.[Obs.] Blackstone.
puppy: The young of a canine animal, esp. of the common dog; a whelp.
parapherna: The property of a woman which, on her marriage, was not made apart of her dower, but remained her own.
pilot valve: A small hand-operated valve to admit liquid to operate a valvedifficult to turn by hand.
plummy: Of the nature of a plum; desirable; profitable; advantageous.[Colloq.] "For the sake of getting something plummy." G. Eliot.
padar: Groats; coarse flour or meal. [Obs.] Sir. H. Wotton.
pantochronometer: An instrument combining a compass, sundial, and universal timedial. Brande & C.
pinweed: Any plant of the genus Lechea, low North American herbs withbranching stems, and very small and abundant leaves and flowers.
permeable: Capable of being permeated, or passed through; yieldingpassage; passable; penetrable; -- used especially of substances whichallow the passage of fluids; as, wood is permeable to oil; glass ispermeable to light. I. Taylor.
potoo: A large South American goatsucker (Nyctibius grandis).
phoca: A genus of seals. It includes the common harbor seal and alliedspecies. See Seal.
predeclare: To declare or announce beforehand; to preannounce. Milman.
psylla: Any leaping plant louse of the genus Psylla, or familyPsyllidæ.
pine: Woe; torment; pain. [Obs.] "Pyne of hell." Chaucer.
pustulate: To form into pustules, or blisters.
podarthrum: The foot joint; in birds, the joint between the metatarsus andthe toes.
premier: The first minister of state; the prime minister.
pentacrinin: A red and purple pigment found in certain crinoids of the genusPentacrinus.
palmarium: One of the bifurcations of the brachial plates of a crinoid.
potency: The quality or state of being potent; physical or moral power;inherent strength; energy; ability to effect a purpose; capability;efficacy; influence. "Drugs of potency." Hawthorne.A place of potency and away o' the state. Shak.
penologist: One versed in, or a student of, penology.
proximity: The quality or state of being next in time, place, causation,influence, etc.; immediate nearness, either in place, blood, oralliance.If he plead proximity of blood That empty title is with easewithstood. Dryden.
pendicler: An inferior tenant; one who rents a pendicle or croft. [Scot.]Jamieson.
pellmell: In utter confusion; with confused violence. "Men, horses,chariots, crowded pellmell." Milton.
prefecture: The office, position, or jurisdiction of a prefect; also, hisofficial residence.
para grass: A valuable pasture grass (Panicum barbinode) introduced intothe Southern United States from Brazil.
pleuralgia: Pain in the side or region of the ribs.
pudendum: The external organs of generation, especially of the female;the vulva.
precoracoid: The anterior part of the coracoid (often closely united withthe clavicle) in the shoulder girdle of many reptiles and amphibians.
pitch: See Pitchstone. Amboyna pitch, the resin of Dammara australis.See Kauri.-- Burgundy pitch. See under Burgundy.-- Canada pitch, the resinous exudation of the hemlock tree (AbiesCanadensis); hemlock gum.-- Jew's pitch, bitumen.-- Mineral pitch. See Bitumen and Asphalt.-- Pitch coal (Min.), bituminous coal.-- Pitch peat (Min.), a black homogeneous peat, with a waxy luster.-- Pitch pine (Bot.), any one of several species of pine, yieldingpitch, esp. the Pinus rigida of North America.
podocarp: A stem, or footstalk, supporting the fruit.
prosaicism: The quality or state of being prosaic; a prosaic manner orstyle. [R.] Poe.
pluralism: The state of a pluralist; the holding of more than oneecclesiastical living at a time. [Eng.]
puerco: A hog. Puerco beds (Geol.), a name given to certain stratabelonging to the earliest Eocene. They are developed in NorthwesternNew Mexico, along the Rio Puerco, and are characterized by theirmammalian remains.
pinule: One of the sights of an astrolabe. [Obs.]
prase: A variety of cryptocrystalline of a leek-green color.
philanthropinism: A system of education on so-called natural principles,attempted in Germany in the last century by Basedow, of Dessau.
pastorale: A composition in a soft, rural style, generally in 6-8 or 12-8time.
pluri-: A combining form from L. plus, pluris, more, many; aspluriliteral.
pyrogallate: A salt of pyrogallic acid; an ether of pyrogallol.
pagoda: A gold or silver coin, of various kinds and values, formerlycurrent in India. The Madras gold pagoda was worth about three and ahalf rupees.
putrescible: Capable of putrefaction; liable to become putrid; as,putrescible substances.
paedogenesis: Reproduction by young or larval animals.
poikilocyte: An irregular form of corpuscle found in the blood in cases ofprofound anæmia, probably a degenerated red blood corpuscle.
parturient: Bringing forth, or about to bring forth, young; fruitful. Jer.Tailor.
polytheize: To adhere to, advocate, or inculcate, the doctrine ofpolytheism. Milman.
peccavi: I have sinned; -- used colloquially to express confession oracknowledgment of an offense. Aubrey.
pseudo-bulb: An aërial corm, or thickened stem, as of some epiphyticorchidaceous plants.
precession: The act of going before, or forward. Lunisolar precession.(Astron.) See under Lunisolar.-- Planetary precession, that part of the precession of theequinoxes which depends on the action of the planets alone.-- Precession of the equinoxes (Astron.), the slow backward motionof the equinoctial points along the ecliptic, at the rate of 50.2"annually, caused by the action of the sun, moon, and planets, uponthe protuberant matter about the earth's equator, in connection withits diurnal rotation; -- so called because either equinox, owing toits westerly motion, comes to the meridian sooner each day than thepoint it would have occupied without the motion of precession, andthus precedes that point continually with reference to the time oftransit and motion.
pointleted: Having a small, distinct point; apiculate. Henslow.
proconsulate: The office jurisdiction of a proconsul, or the term of hisoffice.
potluck: Whatever may chance to be in the pot, or may be provided for ameal.A woman whose potluck was always to be relied on. G. Eliot.To take potluck, to take what food may chance to be provided.
precognosce: To examine beforehand, as witnesses or evidence.A committee of nine precognoscing the chances. Masson.
pycnite: A massive subcolumnar variety of topaz.
pterygopodium: A specially modified part of the ventral fin in maleelasmobranchs, which serves as a copulatory organ, or clasper.
papillulate: Having a minute papilla in the center of a larger elevation ordepression.
ptyxis: The way in which a leaf is sometimes folded in the bud.
pannier: A shield of basket work formerly used by archers as a shelterfrom the enemy's missiles.
purpurogenous: Having the power to produce a purple color; as, thepurpurogenous membrane, or choroidal epithelium, of the eye. SeeVisual purple, under Visual.
pralltriller: A melodic embellishment consisting of the quick alternation ofa principal tone with an auxiliary tone above it, usually the next ofthe scale; --called also the inverted mordente.
polysynthesis: The formation of a word by the combination of several simplewords, as in the aboriginal languages of America; agglutination.Latham.
petaliform: Having the form of a petal; petaloid; petal-shaped.
polymer: Any one of two or more substances related to each other bypolymerism; specifically, a substance produced from another substanceby chemical polymerization. [Formerly also written polymere.]
plerophory: Fullness; full persuasion. "A plerophory of assurance." Bp.Hall.
pilot: One employed to steer a vessel; a helmsman; a steersman.Dryden.
patience: A kind of dock (Rumex Patientia), less common in America thanin Europe; monk's rhubarb.
parole: A watchword given only to officers of guards; -- distinguishedfrom countersign, which is given to all guards.
pegmatitic: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, pegmatite; as, the pegmaticstructure of certain rocks resembling graphic granite.
predomination: The act or state of predominating; ascendency; predominance. W.Browne.
primero: A game at cards, now unknown. Shak.
pupivora: A group of parasitic Hymenoptera, including the ichneumonflies, which destroy the larvæ and pupæ of insects.
prospectus: A summary, plan, or scheme of something proposed, affording aprospect of its nature; especially, an exposition of the scheme of anunpublished literary work.
potentiality: The quality or state of being potential; possibility, notactuality; inherent capability or disposition, not actuallyexhibited.
perimeter: The outer boundary of a body or figure, or the sum of all thesides.
pitpan: A long, flat-bottomed canoe, used for the navigation of riversand lagoons in Central America. Squier.
projectile: A part of mechanics which treats of the motion, range, time offlight, etc., of bodies thrown or driven through the air by animpelling force.
paranymphal: Bridal; nuptial. [R.]At some paranymphal feast. Ford.
plattdeutsch: The modern dialects spoken in the north of Germany, takencollectively; modern Low German. See Low German, under German.
pointingstock: An object of ridicule or scorn; a laughingstock. Shak.
privatdocent: In the universities of Germany and some other Europeancountries, a licensed teacher or lecturer having no share in theuniversity government and dependent upon fees for remuneration.
ping: The sound made by a bullet in striking a solid object or inpassing through the air.
piu: A little more; as, più allegro, a little more briskly.
phlegmon: Purulent inflammation of the cellular or areolar tissue.
pronaos: The porch or vestibule of a temple.
photogen: A light hydrocarbon oil resembling kerosene. It is obtained bydistilling coal, paraffin, etc., and is used as a lubricant,illuminant, etc. [Written also photogene.]
purtenance: That which pertains or belongs to something; esp., the heard,liver, and lungs of an animal. [Obs.] " The purtenaunces ofpurgatory." Piers Plowman.Roast [it] with fire, his head with his legs, and with the purtenance[Rev. Ver., inwards] thereof. Ex. xii. 9.
preemption: The act or right of purchasing before others. Specifically:(a) The privilege or prerogative formerly enjoyed by the king ofbuying provisions for his household in preference to others. [Eng.](b) The right of an actual settler upon public lands (particularlythose of the United States) to purchase a certain portion at a fixedprice in preference to all other applicants. Abbott.
preformative: A formative letter at the beginning of a word. M. Stuart.
pyrocitric: Pertaining to, or designating, any one of three acids obtainedby the distillation of citric acid, and called respectivelycitraconic, itaconic, and mesaconic acid.
peise: A weight; a poise. [Obs.] "To weigh pence with a peise." PiersPlowman.
post-tympanic: Situated behind the tympanum, or in the skull, behind theauditory meatus.
pewtery: Belonging to, or resembling, pewter; as, a pewtery taste.
psychal: Of or pertaining to the soul; psychical. Bayne.
pudic: Of or pertaining to the external organs of generation.
pickthank: One who strives to put another under obligation; an officiousperson; hence, a flatterer. Used also adjectively.Smiling pickthanks, and base newsmongers. Shak.
pseudomorphism: The state of having, or the property of taking, a crystallineform unlike that which belongs to the species.
pickpenny: A miser; also, a sharper. Dr. H. More.
pebrine: An epidemic disease of the silkworm, characterized by thepresence of minute vibratory corpuscles in the blood.
pimple: Any small acuminated elevation of the cuticle, whether going onto suppuration or not. "All eyes can see a pimple on her nose." Pope.
polemics: The art or practice of disputation or controversy, especiallyon religious subjects; that branch of theological science whichpertains to the history or conduct of ecclesiastical controversy.
primly: In a prim or precise manner.
purificatory: Serving or tending to purify; purificative.
phrenological: Of or pertaining to phrenology.-- Phren`o*log"ic*al*ly, adv.
pomme: Having the ends terminating in rounded protuberances or singleballs; -- said of a cross.
paymaster: One who pays; one who compensates, rewards, or requites;specifically, an officer or agent of a government, a corporation, oran employer, whose duty it is to pay salaries, wages, etc., and keepaccount of the same.
prosody: That part of grammar which treats of the quantity of syllables,of accent, and of the laws of versification or metrical composition.
psychian: Any small moth of the genus Psyche and allied genera (familyPsychidæ). The larvæ are called basket worms. See Basket worm, underBasket.
poenamu: A variety of jade or nephrite, -- used in New Zealand for themanufacture of axes and weapons.
proem: Preface; introduction; preliminary observations; prelude.Thus much may serve by way of proem. Swift.
princekin: A petty prince; a princeling.The princekins of private life. Thackeray.
parsonish: Appropriate to, or like, a parson; -- used in disparagement.[Colloq.]
puffiness: The quality or state of being puffy.
pennywort: A European trailing herb (Linaria Cymbalaria) with roundish,reniform leaves. It is often cultivated in hanging baskets. March, orWater, pennywort. (Bot.) See under March.
peritrochium: The wheel which, together with the axle, forms the axis inperitrochio, which see under Axis.
pillorize: To set in, or punish with, the pillory; to pillory. [R.]
patricianism: The rank or character of patricians.
podagra: Gout in the joints of the foot; -- applied also to gout inother parts of body.
putrefy: To become putrid; to decay offensively; to rot. Isa. 1. 6.
pitchblende: A pitch-black mineral consisting chiefly of the oxide ofuranium; uraninite. See Uraninite.
pectic: Of or pertaining to pectin; specifically, designating an acidobtained from ordinary vegetable jelly (pectin) as an amorphoussubstance, tough and horny when dry, but gelatinous when moist.
peculiarness: The quality or state of being peculiar; peculiarity. Mede.
praecognita: This previously known, or which should be known in order tounderstand something else.
provincialist: One who lives in a province; a provincial.
philopena: A present or gift which is made as a forfeit in a social gamethat is played in various ways; also, the game itself. [Written alsofillipeen and phillippine.]
paraphrase: A restatement of a text, passage, or work, expressing themeaning of the original in another form, generally for the sake ofits clearer and fuller exposition; a setting forth the significationof a text in other and ampler terms; a free translation or rendering;-- opposed to metaphrase.In paraphrase, or translation with latitude, the author's words arenot so strictly followed as his sense. Dryden.Excellent paraphrases of the Psalms of David. I. Disraeli.His sermons a living paraphrase upon his practice. Sowth.The Targums are also called the Chaldaic or Aramaic Paraphrases.Shipley.
popping: a. & n. from Pop. Popping crease. (Cricket) See under Crease.
preconcert: To concert or arrange beforehand; to settle by previousagreement.
packer: A person whose business is to pack things; especially, one whopacks food for preservation; as, a pork packer.
prescriptibility: , The quality or state of being prescriptible. Story.
pingle: A small piece of inclosed ground. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
peristaltic: Applied to the peculiar wormlike wave motion of the intestinesand other similar structures, produced by the successive contractionof the muscular fibers of their walls, forcing their contentsonwards; as, peristaltic movement.-- Per`i*stal"tic*al*ly, adv.
perfunctorily: In a perfunctory manner; formally; carelessly. Boyle.
paulownia: A genus of trees of the order Scrophulariaceæ, consisting ofone species, Paulownia imperialis.
presidentship: The office and dignity of president; presidency. Hooker.
phantom circuit: The equivalent of an additional circuit or wire, in reality notexisting, obtained by certain arrangements of real circuits, as insome multiplex telegraph systems.
peag: A kind of aboriginal shell money, or wampum, of the Atlanticcoast of the United States; -- originally applied only to polishedwhite cylindrical beads.
petalism: A form of sentence among the ancient Syracusans by which theybanished for five years a citizen suspected of having dangerousinfluence or ambition. It was similar to the ostracism in Athens; butolive leaves were used instead of shells for ballots.
procreate: To generate and produce; to beget; to engender.
pritchel: A tool employed by blacksmiths for punching or enlarging thenail holes in a horseshoe.
poculent: Fit for drink. [Obs.] "Some those herbs which are not esculent,are . . . poculent." Bacon.
paratactic: Of pertaining to, or characterized by, parataxis.
papistry: The doctrine and ceremonies of the Church of Rome; popery. [R.]Whitgift.
polyphagy: The practice or faculty of subsisting on many kinds of food.
pseudoneuropterous: Of or pertaining to the Pseudoneuroptera.
pyrethrine: An alkaloid extracted from the root of the pellitory of Spain(Anacyclus pyrethrum).
polyglottous: Speaking many languages; polyglot. [R.] "The polyglottoustribes of America." Max Müller.
polyschematist: Having, or existing in, many different forms or fashions;multiform.
pieman: A man who makes or sells pies.
pterygomaxillary: Of or pertaining to the inner pterygoid plate, or pterygoidbone, and the lower jaw.
placeman: One who holds or occupies a place; one who has office undergovernment. Sir W. Scott.
pleadable: Capable of being pleaded; capable of being alleged in proof,defense, or vindication; as, a right or privilege pleadable at law.Dryden.
positional: Of or pertaining to position.Ascribing unto plants positional operations. Sir T. Browne.
palindrome: A word, verse, or sentence, that is the same when read backwardor forward; as, madam; Hannah; or Lewd did I live, & evil I did dwel.
paradigmatize: To set forth as a model or example. [Obs.] Hammond.
plenal: Full; complete; as, a plenal view or act. [Obs.]
psychism: The doctrine of Quesne, that there is a fluid universallydiffused, end equally animating all living beings, the difference intheir actions being due to the difference of the individualorganizations. Fleming.
physostomi: An order of fishes in which the air bladder is provided with aduct, and the ventral fins, when present, are abdominal. It includesthe salmons, herrings, carps, catfishes, and others.
protocanonical: Of or pertaining to the first canon, or that which contains theauthorized collection of the books of Scripture; -- opposed todeutero-canonical.
pteridophyta: A class of flowerless plants, embracing ferns, horsetails, clubmosses, quillworts, and other like plants. See the Note underCryptogamia.-- Pter"i*do*phyte`, n.
palatize: To modify, as the tones of the voice, by means of the palate;as, to palatize a letter or sound.-- Pal`a*ti*za"tion, n. J. Peile.
parenthesis: One of the curved lines () which inclose a parenthetic word orphrase.
pharynx: The part of the alimentary canal between the cavity of themouth and the esophagus. It has one or two external openings throughthe nose in the higher vertebrates, and lateral branchial openings infishes and some amphibias.
periptery: The region surrounding a moving body, such as the wing of abird or a gliding aëroplane, within which cyclic or vortical motionof the air occur.
premaxillary: Situated in front of the maxillary bones; pertaining to thepremaxillæ; intermaxillary.-- n.
pelf: Money; riches; lucre; gain; -- generally conveying the idea ofsomething ill-gotten or worthless. It has no plural. "Mucky pelf."Spenser. "Paltry pelf." Burke.Can their pelf prosper, not got by valor or industry Fuller.
patamar: A vessel resembling a grab, used in the coasting trade ofBombay and Ceylon. [Written also pattemar.]
prostration: A latent, not an exhausted, state of the vital energies; greatoppression of natural strength and vigor.
prop: A shell, used as a die. See Props.
pulverable: Capable of being reduced to fine powder. Boyle.
picoline: Any one of three isometric bases (C6H7N) related to pyridine,and obtained from bone oil, acrolein ammonia, and coal-tar naphtha,as colorless mobile liquids of strong odor; -- called also methylpyridine.
prian: A fine, white, somewhat friable clay; also, the ore containedin a mixture of clay and pebbles. [Written also pryan.]
pyin: An albuminoid constituent of pus, related to mucin, possibly amixture of substances rather than a single body.
proparoxytone: A word which has the acute accent on the antepenult.
pioned: A Shakespearean word of disputed meaning; perh., "abounding inmarsh marigolds."Thy banks with pioned and twilled brims. Shak.
pithiness: The quality or state of being pithy.
prelate: A clergyman of a superior order, as an archbishop or a bishop,having authority over the lower clergy; a dignitary of the church.
pitter: A contrivance for removing the pits from peaches, plums, andother stone fruit.
pennyweight: A troy weight containing twenty-four grains, or the twentiethpart of an ounce; as, a pennyweight of gold or of arsenic. It wasanciently the weight of a silver penny, whence the name.
postea: The return of the judge before whom a cause was tried, after averdict, of what was done in the cause, which is indorsed on the nisiprius record. Wharton.
poultry: Domestic fowls reared for the table, or for their eggs orfeathers, such as cocks and hens, capons, turkeys, ducks, and geese.
parquetry: A species of joinery or cabinet-work consisting of an inlay ofgeometric or other patterns, generally of different colors, -- usedespecially for floors.
perceptivity: The quality or state of being perceptive; power of perception.Locke.
plop: To fall, drop, or move in any way, with a sudden splash orslap, as on the surface of water.
prehallux: An extra first toe, or rudiment of a toe, on the preaxial sideof the hallux.
pulpited: Placed in a pulpit. [R.]Sit . . . at the feet of a pulpited divine. Milton.
plectrum: A small instrument of ivory, wood, metal, or quill, used inplaying upon the lyre and other stringed instruments.
polka: A lively Bohemian or Polish dance tune in 2-4 measure, with thethird quaver accented. Polka jacket, a kind of knit jacket worn bywomen.
pontificality: The state and government of the pope; the papacy. [R.] Bacon.
plaquette: A small plaque, esp., in modern medal engraving, a small anddelicate bas-relief, whether cast or struck from a die, or of formother than circular.
pentoic: Pertaining to, or desingating, an acid (called also valericacid) derived from pentane.
porkwood: The coarse-grained brownish yellow wood of a small tree(Pisonia obtusata) of Florida and the West Indies. Also called pigeonwood, beefwood, and corkwood.
polonaise: Of or pertaining to the Poles, or to Poland. [Written alsoPolonese.]
pedestrian: Going on foot; performed on foot; as, a pedestrian journey.
petty: Little; trifling; inconsiderable; also, inferior; subordinate;as, a petty fault; a petty prince. Denham.Like a petty god I walked about, admired of all. Milton.Petty averages. See under Average.-- Petty cash, money expended or received in small items or amounts.-- Petty officer, a subofficer in the navy, as a gunner, etc.,corresponding to a noncommissionned officer in the army.
protovertebra: One of the primitive masses, or segments, into which themesoblast of the vertebrate embryo breaks up on either side of theanterior part of the notochord; a mesoblastic, or protovertebral,somite. See Illust. of Ectoderm.
password: A word to be given before a person is allowed to pass; awatchword; a countersign. Macaulay.
pilot flag: The flag hoisted at the fore by a vessel desiring a pilot, inthe United States the union jack, in Great Britain the British unionjack with a white border.
plumbagin: A crystalline substance said to be found in the root of acertain plant of the Leadwort (Plumbago) family.
prevertebral: Situated immediately in front, or on the ventral side, of thevertebral column; prespinal.
praenares: The anterior nares. See Nares. B. G. Wilder.
purslane: An annual plant (Portulaca oleracea), with fleshy, succulent,obovate leaves, sometimes used as a pot herb and for salads,garnishing, and pickling. Flowering purslane, or Great floweredpurslane, the Portulaca grandiflora. See Portulaca.-- Purslane tree, a South African shrub (Portulacaria Afra) withmany small opposite fleshy obovate leaves.-- Sea purslane, a seashore plant (Arenaria peploides) with crowdedopposite fleshy leaves.-- Water purslane, an aquatic plant (Ludwiqia palustris) butslightly resembling purslane.
possessory: Of or pertaining to possession, either as a fact or a right; ofthe nature of possession; as, a possessory interest; a possessorylord. Possessory action or suit (Law), an action to regain or obtainpossession of something. See under Petitory.
puzzel: A harlot; a drab; a hussy. [Obs.] Shak.
pregnantly: In a pregnant manner; fruitfully; significantly.
phlebotomy: The act or practice of opening a vein for letting blood, in thetreatment of disease; venesection; bloodletting.
pomarine: Having the nostril covered with a scale. Pomarine jager(Zoöl.), a North Atlantic jager (Stercorarius pomarinus) having theelongated middle tail feathers obtuse. The adult is black.
pluviose: The fifth month of the French republican calendar adopted in1793. It began January 20, and ended February 18. See Vendémiaire.
performance: The act of performing; the carrying into execution or action;execution; achievement; accomplishment; representation by action; as,the performance of an undertaking of a duty.Promises are not binding where the performance is impossible. Paley.
preponderant: Preponderating; outweighing; overbalancing; -- used literallyand figuratively; as, a preponderant weight; of preponderantimportance.-- Pre*pon"der*ant*ly, adv.
peritomous: Cleaving in more directions than one, parallel to the axis.
primigenial: First born, or first of all; original; primary. SeePrimogenial.
pedomotive: Moved or worked by the action of the foot or feet on a pedal ortreadle.
perigean: Pertaining to the perigee. Perigean tides, those spring tideswhich occur soon after the moon passes her perigee.
procrastinator: One who procrastinates, or defers the performance of anything.
pocket: A hole or space covered by a movable piece of board, as in afloor, boxing, partitions, or the like.
pile: A covering of hair or fur.
propheticalness: The quality or state of being prophetical; power or capacity toforetell.
physoclisti: An order of teleost in which the air bladder has no opening.
periople: The external smooth horny layer of the hoof of the horse andallied animals.
puree: A dish made by boiling any article of food to a pulp andrubbing it through a sieve; as, a purée of fish, or of potatoes;especially, a soup the thickening of which is so treated.
piedouche: A pedestal of small size, used to support small objects, asbusts, vases, and the like.
punctured: Produced by puncture; having the characteristics of a puncture;as, a punctured wound.
personnel: The body of persons employed in some public service, as thearmy, navy, etc.; -- distinguished from matériel.
palus: One of several upright slender calcareous processes whichsurround the central part of the calicle of certain corals.
prelusive: Of the nature of a prelude; introductory; indicating thatsomething of a like kind is to follow. "Prelusive drops." Thomson. --Pre*lu"sive*ly, adv.
plot-proof: Secure against harm by plots. Shak.
provable: Capable of being proved; demonstrable.-- Prov"a*ble*ness, n.-- Prov"a*bly, adv.
permitter: One who permits.A permitter, or not a hinderer, of sin. J. Edwards.
plodding: Progressing in a slow, toilsome manner; characterized bylaborious diligence; as, a plodding peddler; a plodding student; aman of plodding habits. --Plod"ding*ly, adv.
procrustes: A celebrated legendary highwayman of Attica, who tied hisvictims upon an iron bed, and, as the case required, either stretchedor cut of their legs to adapt them to its length; -- whence themetaphorical phrase, the bed of Procrustes.
pursuit: Prosecution. [Obs.]That pursuit for tithes ought, and of ancient time did pertain to thespiritual court. Fuller.Curve of pursuit (Geom.), a curve described by a point which is ateach instant moving towards a second point, which is itself movingaccording to some specified law.
patrimonial: Of or pertaining to a patrimony; inherited from ancestors; as,a patrimonial estate.
pot-bellied: Having a protuberant belly, like the bottom of a pot.
profile: A human head represented sidewise, or in a side view; the sideface or half face.
prefatorily: In a prefatory manner; by way of preface.
pyrophosphoric: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid, H4P2O7, which isobtained as a white crystalline substance. Its salts are obtained byheating the phosphates.
prettyism: Affectation of a pretty style, manner, etc. [R.] Ed. Rev.
punchinello: A punch; a buffoon; originally, in a puppet show, a characterrepresented as fat, short, and humpbacked. Spectator.
ptyalin: An unorganized amylolytic ferment, on enzyme, present in humanmixed saliva and in the saliva of some animals.
pavonian: Of or pertaining to a peacock. [R.] Southey.
palter: To trifle with; to waste; to squander in paltry ways or onworthless things. [Obs.] "Palter out your time in the penalstatutes." Beau. & Fl.
pelecaniformes: Those birds that are related to the pelican; the Totipalmi.
prospect: To look over; to explore or examine for something; as, toprospect a district for gold.
permittee: One to whom a permission or permit is given.
pedigree: A record of the lineage or strain of an animal, as of a horse.
polar: Pertaining to, reckoned from, or having a common radiatingpoint; as, polar coördinates. Polar axis, that axis of anastronomical instrument, as an equatorial, which is parallel to theearths axis.-- Polar bear (Zoöl.), a large bear (Ursus, or Thalarctos,maritimus) inhabiting the arctic regions. It sometimes measuresnearly nine feet in length and weighs 1,600 pounds. It is partiallyamphibious, very powerful, and the most carnivorous of all the bears.The fur is white, tinged with yellow. Called also White bear. SeeBear.-- Polar body, cell, or globule (Biol.), a minute cell whichseparates by karyokinesis from the ovum during its maturation. In thematuration of ordinary ova two polar bodies are formed, but inparthogenetic ova only one. The first polar body formed is usuallylarger than the second one, and often divides into two after itsseparation from the ovum. Each of the polar bodies removes maternalchromatin from the ovum to make room for the chromatin of thefertilizing spermatozoön; but their functions are not fullyunderstood.-- Polar circles (Astron. & Geog.), two circles, each at a distancefrom a pole of the earth equal to the obliquity of the ecliptic, orabout 23º 28', the northern called the arctic circle, and thesouthern the antarctic circle.-- Polar clock, a tube, containing a polarizing apparatus, turningon an axis parallel to that of the earth, and indicating the hour ofthe day on an hour circle, by being turned toward the plane ofmaximum polarization of the light of the sky, which is always 90ºfrom the sun.-- Polar coördinates. See under 3d Coördinate.-- Polar dial, a dial whose plane is parallel to a great circlepassing through the poles of the earth. Math. Dict.-- Polar distance, the angular distance of any point on a spherefrom one of its poles, particularly of a heavenly body from the northpole of the heavens.-- Polar equation of a line or surface, an equation which expressesthe relation between the polar coördinates of every point of the lineor surface.-- Polar forces (Physics), forces that are developed and act inpairs, with opposite tendencies or properties in the two elements, asmagnetism, electricity, etc.-- Polar hare (Zoöl.), a large hare of Arctic America (Lepusarcticus), which turns pure white in winter. It is probably a varietyof the common European hare (L. timidus).-- Polar lights, the aurora borealis or australis.-- Polar, or Polaric, opposition or contrast (Logic), an oppositionor contrast made by the existence of two opposite conceptions whichare the extremes in a species, as white and black in colors; hence,as great an opposition or contrast as possible.-- Polar projection. See under Projection.-- Polar spherical triangle (Spherics), a spherical triangle whosethree angular points are poles of the sides of a given triangle. See4th Pole, 2.-- Polar whale (Zoöl.), the right whale, or bowhead. See Whale.
premunitory: Of or pertaining to a premunire; as, a premunitory process.
postpositive: Placed after another word; as, a postpositive conjunction; apostpositive letter.-- Post*pos"i*tive*ly, adv.
preeminent: Eminent above others; prominent among those who are eminent;superior in excellence; surpassing, or taking precedence of, others;rarely, surpassing others in evil, or in bad qualities; as,preëminent in guilt.In goodness and in power preëminent. Milton.
panspermic: Of or pertaining to panspermy; as, the panspermic hypothesis.
plat: To form by interlaying interweaving; to braid; to plait. "Theyhad platted a crown of thorns." Matt. xxvii. 29.
palimpsest: A parchment which has been written upon twice, the firstwriting having been erased to make place for the second. Longfellow.
pursue: To follow a matter judicially, as a complaining party; to actas a prosecutor. Burrill.
pentylic: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, pentyl; as,pentylic alcohol
pollard: To lop the tops of, as trees; to poll; as, to pollard willows.Evelyn.
preludial: Of or pertaining to a prelude; of the nature of a prelude;introductory. [R.]
playday: A day given to play or diversion; a holiday. Swift.
perforative: Having power to perforate or pierce.
penannular: Nearly annular; having nearly the form of a ring. "Penannularrelics." D. Wilson.
psalmograph: A writer of psalms; a psalmographer.
purset: A purse or purse net. B. Jonson.
placentalia: A division of Mammalia including those that have a placenta, orall the orders above the marsupials.
parietes: The walls of a cavity or an organ; as, the abdominal parietes;the parietes of the cranium.
pharyngotome: An instrument for incising or scarifying the tonsils, etc.
publicity pamphlet: A pamphlet which, in some States of the United States havingthe initiative or referendum, is mailed to the voters to inform themas to the nature of a measure submitted by the initiative orreferendum. The pamphlet contains a copy of the proposed law andarguments for and against it by those favoring and opposing it,respectively.
pancratium: An athletic contest involving both boxing and wrestling.
parasite: Of or pertaining to parasites; living on, or derivingnourishment from, some other living animal or plant. See Parasite, 2& 3. Parasitic gull, Parasitic jager. (Zoöl.) See Jager.-- Par`a*sit"ic*al*ly, adv.-- Par`a*sit"ic*al*ness, n.
pellicle: A thin film formed on the surface of an evaporating solution.
pilaster: An upright architectural member right-angled in plan,constructionally a pier (See Pier, 1 (b)), but architecturallycorresponding to a column, having capital, shaft, and base to agreewith those of the columns of the same order. In most cases theprojection from the wall is one third of its width, or less.
piling: The process of building up, heating, and working, fagots, orpiles, to form bars, etc.
praam: A flat-bottomed boat or lighter, -- used in Holland and theBaltic, and sometimes armed in case of war. [Written also pram, andprame.]
penwiper: A cloth, or other material, for wiping off or cleaning ink froma pen.
piligerous: Bearing hair; covered with hair or down; piliferous.
planetary: Under the dominion or influence of a planet. "Skilled in theplanetary hours." Drayton.
pestalozzianism: The system of education introduced by Pestalozzi.
passeres: An order, or suborder, of birds, including more that half ofall the known species. It embraces all singing birds (Oscines),together with many other small perching birds.
piezometer: An instrument for measuring the compressibility of liquids.
pitchfork: A fork, or farming utensil, used in pitching hay, sheaves ofgrain, or the like.
peristole: Peristaltic action, especially of the intestines.
prosylogism: A syllogism preliminary or logically essential to anothersyllogism; the conclusion of such a syllogism, which becomes apremise of the following syllogism.
pudendal: Of or pertaining to the pudenda, or pudendum.
pineal: Of or pertaining to a pine cone; resembling a pine cone. Pinealgland (Anat.), a glandlike body in the roof of the third ventricle ofthe vertebrate brain; -- called also pineal body, epiphysis,conarium. In some animals it is connected with a rudimentary eye, theso-called pineal eye, and in other animals it is supposed to be theremnant of a dorsal median eye.
polariscope: An instrument consisting essentially of a polarizer and ananalyzer, used for polarizing light, and analyzing its properties.
pulsator: That which beats or throbs in working.
pneumology: The science which treats of the lungs.
polynomial: An expression composed of two or more terms, connected by thesigns plus or minus; as, a2 - 2ab + b2.
packing: A substance or piece used to make a joint impervious; as:(a) A thin layer, or sheet, of yielding or elastic material insertedbetween the surfaces of a flange joint.(b) The substance in a stuffing box, through which a piston rodslides.(c) A yielding ring, as of metal, which surrounds a piston andmaintains a tight fit, as inside a cylinder, etc.
post-mortem: After death; as, post-mortem rigidity. Post-mortem examination(Med.), an examination of the body made after the death of thepatient; an autopsy.
proll: To search or prowl after; to rob; to plunder. [Obs.] Barrow.
perineurium: The connective tissue sheath which surrounds a bundle of nervefibers. See Epineurium, and Neurilemma.
purifier: One who, or that which, purifies or cleanses; a cleanser; arefiner.
photosphere: A sphere of light; esp., the luminous envelope of the sun.
practicability: The quality or state of being practicable; practicableness;feasibility. "The practicability of such a project." Stewart.
pulpy: Like pulp; consisting of pulp; soft; fleshy; succulent; as, thepulpy covering of a nut; the pulpy substance of a peach or a cherry.
petaline: Pertaining to a petal; attached to, or resembling, a petal.
pink-sterned: Having a very narrow stern; -- said of a vessel.
plashet: A small pond or pool; a puddle.
petrificate: To petrify. [Obs.]Our hearts petrificated were. J. Hall (1646).
pursy: Fat and short-breathed; fat, short, and thick; swelled withpampering; as, pursy insolence. Shak.Pursy important he sat him down. Sir W. Scot.
perivisceral: Around the viscera; as, the perivisceral cavity.
powderhorn: A horn in which gunpowder is carried.
pesade: The motion of a horse when, raising his fore quarters, he keepshis hind feet on the ground without advancing; rearing.
paillasse: An under bed or mattress of straw. [Written also palliasse.]
pyrogen: A poison separable from decomposed meat infusions, and supposedto be formed from albuminous matter through the agency of bacteria.
polyeidic: Passing through several distinct larval forms; -- havingseveral distinct kinds of young.
padlock: To fasten with, or as with, a padlock; to stop; to shut; toconfine as by a padlock. Milton. Tennyson.
placit: A decree or determination; a dictum. [Obs.] "The placits andopinions of other philosophers." Evelyn.
pauldron: A piece of armor covering the shoulder at the junction of thebody piece and arm piece.
pantalet: One of the legs of the loose drawers worn by children andwomen; particularly, the lower part of such a garment, coming belowthe knee, often made in a separate piece; -- chiefly in the plural.
perverseness: The quality or state of being perverse. "Virtue hath someperverseness." Donne.
pathopoela: A speech, or figure of speech, designed to move the passion.Smart.
perichaetial: Of or pertaining to the perichæth.
psephism: A proposition adopted by a majority of votes; especially, oneadopted by vote of the Athenian people; a statute. J. P. Mahaffy.
papaverine: An alkaloid found in opium. It has a weaker therapeutic actionthan morphine.
promorphology: Crystallography of organic forms; -- a division of morphologycreated by Haeckel. It is essentially stereometric, and relates to amathematical conception of organic forms. See Tectology.
pterostigma: A thickened opaque spot on the wings of certain insects.
polygon: A plane figure having many angles, and consequently many sides;esp., one whose perimeter consists of more than four sides; anyfigure having many angles. Polygon of forces (Mech.), a polygonalfigure, the sides of which, taken successively, represent, in lengthand direction, several forces acting simultaneously upon one point,so that the side necessary to complete the figure represents theresultant of those forces. Cf. Parallelogram of forces, underParallelogram.
photomezzotype: A photomechanical process similar to collotype.
promenade: To walk for pleasure, display, or exercise.
parer: One who, or that which, pares; an instrument for paring.
platyptera: A division of Pseudoneuroptera including the species which havefour broad, flat wings, as the termites, or white-ants, and the stoneflies (Perla).
pectostraca: A degenerate order of Crustacea, including the Rhizocephala andCirripedia.
priestery: Priests, collectively; the priesthood; -- so called incontempt. [R.] Milton.
pepper: The plant which yields pepper, an East Indian woody climber(Piper nigrum), with ovate leaves and apetalous flowers in spikesopposite the leaves. The berries are red when ripe. Also, byextension, any one of the several hundred species of the genus Piper,widely dispersed throughout the tropical and subtropical regions ofthe earth.
pruinose: Frosty; covered with fine scales, hairs, dust, bloom, or thelike, so as to give the appearance of frost.
pericystitis: Inflammation of the tissues surrounding the bladder.
procyon: a star of the first magnitude in the constellation Canis Minor,or the Little Dog.
pistachio green: A light yellowish green color resembling that of the pistachionut.
presumptuousness: The quality or state of being presumptuous.
podo-: A combining form or prefix from Gr. poy`s, podo`s, foot; as,podocarp, podocephalous, podology.
pedagogics: The science or art of teaching; the principles and rules ofteaching; pedagogy.
phoenician: Of or pertaining to Phoenica.-- n.
parol: Oral declaration; word of mouth; also, a writing not underseal. Blackstone.
pyrargyrite: Ruby silver; dark red silver ore. It is a sulphide of antimonyand silver, occurring in rhombohedral crystals or massive, and is ofa dark red or black color with a metallic adamantine luster.
ploc: A mixture of hair and tar for covering the bottom of a ship.
pilled: Stripped of hair; scant of hair; bald. [Obs.] "Pilled beard."Chaucer.
pedunculata: A division of Cirripedia, including the stalked or goosebarnacles.
purist: Of or pertaining to purists or purism.
prevent: To come before the usual time. [Obs.]Strawberries . . . will prevent and come early. Bacon.
pyrite: A common mineral of a pale brass-yellow color and brilliantmetallic luster, crystallizing in the isometric system; iron pyrites;iron disulphide.Hence sable coal his massy couch extends, And stars of gold thesparkling pyrite blends. E. Darwin.
priced: Rated in price; valued; as, high-priced goods; low-pricedlabor.
pyrheliometer: An instrument for measuring the direct heating effect of thesun's rays.
politzerization: The act of inflating the middle ear by blowing air up the noseduring the act of swallowing; -- so called from Prof. Politzer ofVienna, who first practiced it.
prosiliency: The act of leaping forth or forward; projection. "Suchprosiliency of relief." Coleridge.
pestilently: In a pestilent manner; mischievously; destructively. "Above allmeasure pestilently noisome." Dr. H. More.
planer tree: A small-leaved North American tree (Planera aquatica) relatedto the elm, but having a wingless, nutlike fruit.
prosthesis: The addition to the human body of some artificial part, toreplace one that is wanting, as a log or an eye; -- called alsoprothesis.
ponderary: Of or pertaining to weight; as, a ponderary system. [R.]M'Culloch.
poledavy: A sort of coarse canvas; poldway. [Obs.] Howell.
prolongable: Capable of being prolonged; as, life is prolongable by care.Each syllable being a prolongable quantity. Rush.
pocky: Full of pocks; affected with smallpox or other eruptivedisease. Bp. Hall.
postulation: The act of postulating, or that which is postulated;assumption; solicitation; suit; cause.
psychozoic: Designating, or applied to the Era of man; as, the psychozoicera.
physianthropy: The philosophy of human life, or the doctrine of theconstitution and diseases of man, and their remedies.
paracrostic: A poetical composition, in which the first verse contains, inorder, the first letters of all the verses of the poem. Brande & C.
platyelminthes: A class of helminthes including the cestodes, or tapeworms, thetrematodes, and the turbellarians. Called also flatworms.
prioress: A lady superior of a priory of nuns, and next in dignity to anabbess.
parotitis: Inflammation of the parotid glands. Epidemic, or Infectious,parotitis, mumps.
paleous: Chaffy; like chaff; paleaceous. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
placebo: The first antiphon of the vespers for the dead.
paver: One who paves; one who lays a pavement. [Written also pavierand pavior.]
panteutonic: Of or pertaining to all the Teutonic races.
preposition: A word employed to connect a noun or a pronoun, in anadjectival or adverbial sense, with some other word; a particle usedwith a noun or pronoun (in English always in the objective case) tomake a phrase limiting some other word; -- so called because usuallyplaced before the word with which it is phrased; as, a bridge ofiron; he comes from town; it is good for food; he escaped by running.
precursive: Preceding; introductory; precursory. "A deep precursive sound."Coleridge.
punctilious: Attentive to punctilio; very nice or exact in the forms ofbehavior, etiquette, or mutual intercourse; precise; exact in thesmallest particulars.
